instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
came in for liquid damage, clean it, and have foldermark questionmark, run slowly with max fan speed, disk utility show nothing on internal, terminal diskutil list doesnt show anything internal ssd too
lifeboat connector is attached, I saw video from paul daniel about connecting missing traces from <RESISTOR>R9350</RESISTOR> to the probe point infront of it, so I did, and still the same question mark folder, then I found out that the <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground, I have tried removing <CAPACITOR>C9402</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9403</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9400</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C9404</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C9401</CAPACITOR>, but short is still present..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
So you have a problem with lifeboat connector for sure.
Board shouldn't start at all, with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground.
So J9600 doesn't close pins 43/44.
Is possible to have other broken connections too.

However, you should eliminate the short first.
If you get the same ohm value to ground at L9400, then remove <TRANSISTOR>Q9401</TRANSISTOR> and check again.
I recommend you to pray a lot, if you want to have a good nand still.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message: removing <TRANSISTOR>Q9041</TRANSISTOR>, but there's still short, so I have to inject voltage to ppbus ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
Why to inject on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> if no short there???

On your board, <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> doesn't make contact with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> anymore.
If you still have short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL>, there is the point to inject.
But I was expecting exact ohm value there, as in L9400 too.

You can have the short on J9600.
Remove lifeboat top plate and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
resistance to ground with red probe on ground L9400 : 3.7 kohm
11.5 k ohm with black probe on ground
removing j9600, but still short on  PPVIN2v7nand_lb
purchasing bench power supply..,a question please, for injecting voltage, the psu must be regulated psu right ? thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
You need regulated power supply, with high current capability.
I already posted some links on the forum.
You can choose 24V/20A, 12V/40A, or even  cheap DPS modules, like DPS5020 from Aliexpress.

Follow the <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> trace on the board.
J9600 looks good, no damage on power pins?
Check <CAPACITOR>C9401</CAPACITOR>-04; start with <CAPACITOR>C9402</CAPACITOR>/03...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message: so i inject 2v there, and my jumper at <RESISTOR>R9350</RESISTOR> disconnected, I tried reconnecting <RESISTOR>R9350</RESISTOR> and the probe point in front of it, now there's no short, but <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> voltage is 13v, and cycling every few second, macbook still alive, <CAPACITOR>C9401</CAPACITOR>-4 looks fine no short

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
Any pulse at L9400?
Do you get 13V at pin 1/<RESISTOR>R9350</RESISTOR>?
Be sure <SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7NAND_LB</SIGNAL> trace has continuity on all its components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
no pulse at L9400, yeah I get 13v at pin 1 or <RESISTOR>R9350</RESISTOR>
all traces is connected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message: i have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL>, so my next option is to only replace <CHIP>U9300</CHIP>, if still can't can nand be replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
I exactly don't know what you did there and the initial state of your board.
This board could be waste of time to go ahead now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message:
I salvage the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> before, but i think its just a waste to go to trash, i can still use this machine as lcd tester..
After i reassemble all salvaged chip (<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>), 
Ppdcin 5v  but looping at all port except at bottom of j3300 which i think correspond to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, i have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
, i have diode mode all 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and all have at least 0.400v at 3 ldo output 1v1 1v8 3v3.. anything i should check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flashing question mark
threads.message: If one port has different behaviour, then still a problem on USB-C areas...
